content.title: Oxygen Therapy
content.summary: Oxygen therapy is the administration of supplemental oxygen to treat hypoxemia. Delivery systems range from low-flow (nasal cannula, simple mask) to high-flow (high-flow nasal cannula, venturi mask) and reservoir systems (non-rebreather). Selection depends on oxygen requirements, patient comfort, and need for precise FiO2 control.
key_points: Nasal cannula: 1-6 L/min delivers approximately 24-44% FiO2; comfortable but imprecise
Venturi mask: delivers precise FiO2 (24-50%) via entrainment; ideal for COPD patients
Non-rebreather: 10-15 L/min with reservoir delivers 80-95% FiO2 for severe hypoxemia
High-flow nasal cannula (HFNC): 30-60 L/min with heated humidity; provides PEEP-like effect and precise FiO2
Target SpO2 88-92% in COPD with chronic hypercapnia to avoid suppressing hypoxic drive
Long-term oxygen therapy (LTOT) improves survival in COPD patients with PaO2 ≤55 mmHg
content.statement: Oxygen is a medication with specific indications, delivery methods, and potential toxicities. Appropriate selection of delivery device and flow rate, guided by target saturation, optimizes oxygenation while minimizing complications.

explanation.intuition: The goal of oxygen therapy is to maintain adequate tissue oxygenation (SpO2 ≥90% or PaO2 ≥60 mmHg in most patients). The inspired oxygen concentration (FiO2) depends on both the oxygen flow rate and the patient's inspiratory flow. High-flow systems match or exceed patient demand, providing consistent FiO2; low-flow systems mix with room air, varying with breathing pattern.
explanation.key_insight: In COPD patients with chronic hypercapnia, excessive oxygen can suppress hypoxic ventilatory drive and worsen CO2 retention (oxygen-induced hypercapnia). Target SpO2 88-92% in these patients. High-flow nasal cannula provides benefits beyond oxygenation: dead space washout, mild PEEP effect, and improved secretion clearance.
explanation.technical_details: Low-flow NC: each L/min adds ~4% FiO2 (starting at 21%); actual FiO2 varies with tidal volume and RR. Venturi: fixed entrainment ratio ensures precise FiO2. HFNC: flows 30-60 L/min with heated humidity at 31-37°C; FiO2 21-100% adjustable; generates 2-8 cmH2O PEEP with closed mouth.

definitions_glossary.oxygen_therapy: Administration of supplemental oxygen to treat or prevent hypoxemia
definitions_glossary.nasal_cannula: Low-flow oxygen delivery via soft prongs in nostrils; 1-6 L/min delivers ~24-44% FiO2
definitions_glossary.simple_face_mask: Covers nose and mouth; 5-10 L/min delivers 35-50% FiO2; requires minimum 5 L/min to prevent CO2 rebreathing
definitions_glossary.venturi_mask: High-flow system using Venturi principle for precise FiO2 delivery via air entrainment
definitions_glossary.non_rebreather_mask: Reservoir mask with one-way valves; 10-15 L/min delivers 80-95% FiO2
definitions_glossary.high_flow_nasal_cannula: HFNC: heated humidified oxygen at 30-60 L/min with precise FiO2; provides mild CPAP effect
definitions_glossary.fio2: Fraction of inspired oxygen; room air is 0.21 (21%)
definitions_glossary.hypoxemia: Low arterial oxygen; PaO2 <60 mmHg or SpO2 <90%
definitions_glossary.hypoxia: Inadequate tissue oxygenation; consequence of uncorrected hypoxemia
definitions_glossary.oxygen_induced_hypercapnia: CO2 retention in COPD patients from excessive O2 suppressing hypoxic drive and V/Q mismatch
definitions_glossary.long_term_oxygen_therapy: LTOT: home oxygen ≥15 hours/day for patients with severe chronic hypoxemia
definitions_glossary.pulse_oximetry: Non-invasive measurement of SpO2 via light absorption; normal ≥95% in healthy adults

pathophysiology.mechanism: Oxygen supplementation increases alveolar PO2, improving the driving gradient for oxygen diffusion into blood. In V/Q mismatch, increasing FiO2 raises PO2 even in poorly ventilated alveoli. In shunt (completely unventilated alveoli), oxygen therapy is less effective because blood bypasses functioning alveoli. Chronic hypoxemia triggers adaptive mechanisms (increased erythropoietin) but also pulmonary vasoconstriction leading to pulmonary hypertension.
key_pathways: Supplemental O2 → increased alveolar PO2 → improved diffusion gradient → increased PaO2
In V/Q mismatch → O2 therapy effective → improved oxygenation
In shunt → limited O2 response → blood bypasses ventilated alveoli
Excessive O2 in COPD → suppressed hypoxic drive + worsened V/Q (Haldane effect) → hypercapnia
pathophysiology.clinical_significance: Oxygen is essential for acute hypoxemia but is also a medication with toxicities. Hyperoxia causes oxidative stress and may worsen outcomes in some conditions (MI, stroke with normal saturation).

primary: PaO2 ≤55 mmHg or SpO2 ≤88% at rest
PaO2 56-59 with cor pulmonale, polycythemia, or pulmonary hypertension
indications_for_ltot.exertional: Significant desaturation (<88%) with exercise in otherwise normoxic patient

oxygen_targets.carbon_monoxide: 100% FiO2 regardless of SpO2 (SpO2 unreliable in CO poisoning)

simple_mask.cons: Must maintain ≥5 L/min to prevent CO2 rebreathing

high_flow_nasal_cannula.pros: Humidified, PEEP effect, dead space washout

non_rebreather.design: Bag with one-way valves preventing exhaled air rebreathing

special_considerations.copd: Start low (1-2 L/min NC or 24-28% Venturi); target SpO2 88-92%; monitor for CO2 retention
special_considerations.hfnc_role: Alternative to NIV for hypoxemic respiratory failure; ROX index predicts failure (SpO2/FiO2)/RR

skos.definition: The therapeutic administration of oxygen at concentrations greater than ambient air to treat or prevent hypoxemia and tissue hypoxia

learning_objectives: Select appropriate oxygen delivery device based on patient oxygen requirements
Describe the principles of low-flow versus high-flow oxygen systems
Apply appropriate oxygen targets for different patient populations (general vs COPD)
Explain the mechanism and management of oxygen-induced hypercapnia
Identify indications for long-term oxygen therapy in COPD
clinical_pearls: Nasal cannula: each 1 L/min ≈ +4% FiO2; actual FiO2 varies with breathing pattern
Non-rebreather at 15 L/min does NOT deliver 100% FiO2 (leaks limit to 80-95%)
HFNC provides ~1 cmH2O PEEP per 10 L/min of flow; washout of dead space improves CO2 clearance
COPD target: 88-92% - avoid both hypoxemia AND hyperoxia
LTOT must be used ≥15 hours/day to improve survival in qualifying COPD patients
Pulse oximetry unreliable in: CO poisoning, methemoglobinemia, severe anemia, nail polish, poor perfusion
common_misconceptions: Non-rebreather delivers 100% FiO2 (actually 80-95% due to leaks)
High flow always means high FiO2 (HFNC can deliver any FiO2 21-100%)
Oxygen is harmless (hyperoxia has toxicities; targets matter)
